data.statement: The legal age for marriage in Liberia is 18 years for both boys and girls.
Access to contraception is a fundamental right for all individuals in Liberia.
Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) is banned in Liberia for girls under the age of 18.
Comprehensive sexuality education empowers young people to make informed health decisions.
Antenatal care visits are crucial for monitoring the health of both the pregnant person and the developing fetus.
HIV testing and counseling services are available and confidential in Liberia.
Gender-based violence is a violation of human rights and includes physical, sexual, and emotional abuse.
Postpartum family planning helps in spacing pregnancies for the health of the mother and child.
The Maternal Mortality Rate in Liberia is one of the highest in the world.
Consent must be freely given, reversible, informed, enthusiastic, and specific for any sexual activity.
Unsafe abortion is a major cause of maternal death in Liberia.
The Liberian government has a National Reproductive Health Policy.
Menstrual hygiene management is essential for the dignity and health of girls and women.
Condoms are the only contraceptive method that protects against both pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections.
Infertility services and support should be accessible to individuals and couples.
Pregnant adolescents face higher risks of complications during childbirth.
The Prevention and Control of HIV and AIDS Act protects people living with HIV from discrimination.
Skin-to-skin contact immediately after birth promotes bonding and helps regulate the newborn's temperature.
Victims of sexual assault have the right to receive medical care and psychosocial support.
Voluntary sterilization is a permanent family planning option available for both women and men.
Pregnant women should be tested for syphilis to prevent mother-to-child transmission.
Child, early, and forced marriage can have severe negative consequences on a girl's health and education.
Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) can prevent HIV infection after a possible exposure if started within 72 hours.
Exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months is recommended for infant health.
Men and boys have a responsibility to promote gender equality and support reproductive health.
Prenatal supplements like folic acid and iron are important for a healthy pregnancy.
Healthcare providers are obligated to maintain patient confidentiality.
Emergency contraception can prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex.
Obstetric fistula is a preventable and treatable childbirth injury.
Everyone has the right to make decisions about their own body without coercion or discrimination.
The 'She Decides' initiative supports the right of women and girls to decide freely on their sexual lives.
HPV vaccination can prevent cervical cancer and is recommended for young adolescents.
Male involvement in reproductive health improves family planning uptake and maternal health outcomes.
A balanced diet is crucial for the health of pregnant and breastfeeding women.
Stigma and discrimination are significant barriers to accessing HIV services.
The 2019 Rape Law amended the Penal Code to include stricter punishments for rape.
Regular self-breast exams can help in the early detection of breast abnormalities.
Pregnancy is measured in trimesters, each lasting about three months.
Sexual and reproductive health services should be accessible to people with disabilities.
Unmet need for family planning refers to women who want to stop or delay childbearing but are not using contraception.
Warning signs during pregnancy include severe headaches, blurred vision, and vaginal bleeding.
Prevention of Mother-To-Child Transmission (PMTCT) services are vital for reducing pediatric HIV.
Sexual rights include the right to have a safe and pleasurable sexual experience.
Traditional birth attendants play a role in rural maternal healthcare but should be linked to the formal health system.
Indicators for SRHR include adolescent birth rate and contraceptive prevalence rate.
Sexually active individuals should get regular check-ups for sexually transmitted infections.
Pregnancy spacing of at least 24 months reduces risks for the mother and the child.
The '1.5.9' Malaria Message is a key health communication in Liberia.
Cervical cancer screening can detect precancerous cells early.
Reproductive cancers include cervical, breast, ovarian, and prostate cancer.
The Sustainable Development Goals include targets for reducing maternal mortality.
A woman has the right to refuse sex, even with her husband.
Postnatal care checks are important for the mother and baby within the first 6 weeks after delivery.
Intrauterine Devices (IUDs) are long-acting reversible contraceptives.
Sexual violence can lead to unintended pregnancies, STIs, and psychological trauma.
Tetanus vaccination is important for pregnant women to protect newborns.
The Ministry of Health is the primary government body responsible for health policy in Liberia.
Myths and misconceptions about contraception are common and should be addressed with accurate information.
A woman's fertility returns shortly after stopping most forms of contraception.
Pre-eclampsia is a dangerous condition characterized by high blood pressure during pregnancy.
The National AIDS Commission coordinates the national response to HIV and AIDS.
Sexual health is not just the absence of disease, but a state of physical, mental, and social well-being.
Male circumcision can reduce the risk of heterosexual HIV transmission in men.
The 'Three Zeroes' framework aims for zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination, and zero AIDS-related deaths.
Obstetric ultrasound can be used to monitor fetal development.
Sexual and reproductive health is a core component of universal health coverage.
The 'One Stop Center' model provides comprehensive services for survivors of sexual and gender-based violence.
Injectable contraceptives are a popular, reversible method in Liberia.
Early signs of pregnancy include a missed period, nausea, and breast tenderness.
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) allows people living with HIV to live long and healthy lives.
Reproductive rights are grounded in internationally recognized human rights.
The Liberia Demographic and Health Survey (LDHS) is a key source of SRHR data.
A woman can get pregnant if she has sex during her period.
Skilled birth attendance is critical for managing childbirth complications.
Syphilis, if left untreated in pregnancy, can cause stillbirth or congenital disabilities.
Economic empowerment of women is linked to better reproductive health outcomes.
The 'Bended Knee' campaign in Liberia raised awareness about sexual and gender-based violence.
Implant contraceptives are effective for up to 3-5 years.
Anemia is a common nutritional disorder among pregnant women in Liberia.
Viral load testing monitors the effectiveness of HIV treatment.
Harmful traditional practices negatively impact the sexual and reproductive health of women and girls.
The menstrual cycle typically lasts between 21 and 35 days.
Family planning saves lives by reducing maternal mortality.
Postpartum depression is a serious mental health condition that can occur after childbirth.
Prevention, not punishment, should be the focus of drug use during pregnancy.
The 'U=U' message means Undetectable equals Untransmittable for people on effective HIV treatment.
Sexual orientation and gender identity are part of human diversity.
Community-based distribution of contraceptives increases access in remote areas.
A balanced diet rich in iron and folic acid is important for adolescent girls.
The 'First 1,000 Days' from conception to a child's second birthday is a critical window for development.
PrEP (Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis) is a daily pill for HIV-negative people at high risk of infection.
Intersectionality recognizes that people face overlapping forms of discrimination.
Telemedicine can be used to provide SRHR information and consultations.
Withdrawal is not an effective method of pregnancy prevention.
Delayed cord clamping after birth is beneficial for the newborn.
Gonorrhea and Chlamydia are common bacterial STIs that can cause infertility if untreated.
Social and Behavior Change Communication is used to promote positive SRHR practices.
The 'Dignity Kit' often contains items for menstrual hygiene and personal safety for women and girls.
Fertility awareness methods require careful tracking of the menstrual cycle.
Kangaroo Mother Care provides warmth and promotes bonding for low-birth-weight babies.
Herpes is a viral STI that has no cure but can be managed.
Youth-friendly health services are designed to be accessible and non-judgmental.
The 'Maputo Protocol' guarantees comprehensive rights for women in Africa, including SRHR.
Oral contraceptive pills must be taken consistently every day.
Gestational diabetes is a form of diabetes that can develop during pregnancy.
Trichomoniasis is a parasitic STI that can increase the risk of acquiring HIV.
Peer education is an effective strategy for reaching adolescents with SRHR information.
The 'Dual Protection' method involves using condoms along with another contraceptive.
A birth plan helps a pregnant person communicate their preferences for labor and delivery.
Hepatitis B and C are viral infections that can be sexually transmitted and affect the liver.
Comprehensive sexuality education should be age-appropriate and scientifically accurate.
The Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) can be a temporary contraceptive for breastfeeding mothers.
Preeclampsia can occur after delivery, known as postpartum preeclampsia.
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is often a complication of untreated STIs.
Adolescent boys also need education about puberty, consent, and responsible sexuality.
Barrier methods of contraception include male and female condoms and diaphragms.
A multiple pregnancy (twins, triplets) requires specialized prenatal care.
The 'Window Period' is the time between HIV infection and when a test can detect it.
Child protection services work to prevent and respond to violence, abuse, and exploitation of children.
Hormonal contraceptives do not protect against sexually transmitted infections.
A miscarriage is the spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before the 20th week.
Opportunistic infections are illnesses that occur more frequently in people with weakened immune systems, like from HIV.
Digital platforms can be used to disseminate SRHR information and counter misinformation.
Vasectomy is a safe and effective permanent contraception method for men.
Pregnancy can occur as a result of rape, and survivors need access to emergency contraception and safe abortion where legal.
The 'Maternal Death Surveillance and Response' system tracks and aims to prevent maternal deaths.
Adherence to antiretroviral therapy is critical for its success.
The 'Right to Health' is enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
The 'Fistula Rehabilitation and Reintegration Program' in Liberia provides surgical repair and support.
The 'Global Gag Rule' restricts US funding to foreign NGOs that provide or advocate for abortion services.
Infertility can be caused by factors in both men and women.
The 'Continuum of Care' for maternal and newborn health links services from pregnancy to postpartum.
Discrimination based on HIV status is illegal and harmful.
The 'No Tolerance' policy in schools aims to protect students from sexual abuse and exploitation.
Subdermal implants are a type of long-acting reversible contraceptive placed under the skin of the upper arm.
Pregnancy is divided into three stages called trimesters.
The 'ABC' strategy for HIV prevention stands for Abstinence, Be Faithful, and use Condoms.
Reproductive health includes the right to a satisfying and safe sex life.
Task-shifting allows mid-level healthcare workers to provide certain SRH services to increase access.
The 'Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative' promotes breastfeeding.
HIV self-testing kits provide a private way to know one's status.
Sexual exploitation is a form of gender-based violence.
The 'Fertility Rate' refers to the average number of children a woman gives birth to in her lifetime.
Ectopic pregnancy is a life-threatening condition where the embryo implants outside the uterus.
The 'WASH' program (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) is crucial for menstrual hygiene and infection prevention in clinics.
The 'Harm Reduction' approach provides services to people who use drugs to minimize health risks.
Sexual harassment is an unwelcome behavior of a sexual nature that creates a hostile environment.
The 'Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health' (RMNCAH) framework provides a holistic approach.
A stillbirth is the loss of a baby after 20 weeks of pregnancy.
The 'Most-at-Risk Populations' for HIV include sex workers, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.
Economic violence, such as denying financial resources, is a form of gender-based violence.
The 'Socio-Ecological Model' examines how individual, relationship, community, and societal factors influence health.
Oxytocin is a hormone used to prevent or treat postpartum hemorrhage.
The 'Know Your Epidemic' approach tailors HIV responses to local context and data.
Psychological violence, including intimidation and constant humiliation, is a form of abuse.
The 'Life Course Approach' to health considers how experiences at different life stages impact long-term well-being.
Misoprostol is a medication used to manage postpartum hemorrhage and for other reproductive health indications.
The '90-90-90' targets aimed for 90% of people with HIV knowing their status, 90% on treatment, and 90% virally suppressed.
The 'Sexual Offenses Bill' in Liberia seeks to reform laws related to sexual violence.
The 'Partograph' is a tool used to monitor labor and detect complications.
Prevention of vertical transmission of Hepatitis B is also important.
The 'Gender Inequality Index' measures disparities between men and women in health, empowerment, and economic status.
The 'Maternal and Child Health Handbook' is a home-based record for pregnancy, childbirth, and childcare.
Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in advanced HIV.
The 'Spotlight Initiative' is a global effort to eliminate violence against women and girls.
The 'Maternal Mortality Ratio' is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.
Tuberculosis is a leading cause of death among people living with HIV.
The 'Child Rights Act' in Liberia defines the rights and responsibilities of children.
The 'Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor' helps prevent postpartum hemorrhage.
The 'Differentiated Service Delivery' model for HIV tailors care to the needs of the patient.
The 'IEC/BCC' strategy uses Information, Education, and Communication/Behavior Change Communication for health promotion.
The 'Maternal Waiting Home' is a facility near a hospital where pregnant women from remote areas can stay before their due date.
The 'Syndromic Management' approach is used to treat STIs based on symptoms in low-resource settings.
The 'Gender Marker' is a tool used to track and ensure funding is allocated for gender equality.
The 'Maternal Near-Miss' refers to a woman who nearly died but survived a complication during pregnancy or childbirth.
The 'Social Determinants of Health' are conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work, and age that impact health outcomes.
The 'Mobility Mapping' tool can be used to understand where adolescents access SRHR services.
The 'Human Papillomavirus' is the primary cause of cervical cancer.
The 'Community Health Assistant' program in Liberia extends basic health services to communities.
The 'Task Force for Global Health' supports various health initiatives, including those for NTDs and immunization.
The 'Essential Package of Health Services' in Liberia defines the minimum services to be provided at each level of the health system.
The 'Health Management Information System' (HMIS) collects and analyzes health data.
The 'Performance-Based Financing' model provides incentives to health facilities for achieving specific targets.
The 'Logistics Management Information System' (LMIS) tracks the supply of medicines and contraceptives.
The 'Cold Chain' is a temperature-controlled supply chain vital for storing vaccines and some contraceptives.
The 'Community-Led Monitoring' approach involves communities in tracking the quality of health services.
The 'Quality of Care' framework for maternal and newborn health includes dimensions like safety, effectiveness, and timeliness.
The 'Respectful Maternity Care' charter outlines the rights of every woman during childbirth.
The 'Person-Centered Care' approach respects the preferences, needs, and values of the individual receiving care.
The 'Informed Choice' principle means individuals make decisions based on comprehensive, understandable information.
The 'Contraceptive Commodity Security' ensures a reliable supply of a variety of contraceptive methods.
The 'Total Market Approach' engages both public and private sectors to meet family planning needs.
The 'Demand Generation' activities create awareness and desire for health services.
The 'Service Delivery Point' is any location where health services are provided, like a clinic or hospital.
The 'Client Exit Interview' is a method to collect feedback from people who have just received services.
The 'Mystery Client' technique involves trained individuals posing as clients to assess service quality.
The 'Gender-Transformative Programming' aims to challenge and change gender norms and power imbalances.
The 'Male Engagement' strategy actively involves men and boys in promoting gender equality and SRHR.
The 'Positive Deviance' approach studies individuals or groups who achieve better outcomes than their peers to identify successful behaviors.
The 'Human-Centered Design' process involves end-users in creating solutions to health challenges.
The 'Implementation Science' studies methods to promote the uptake of research findings into routine practice.
The 'Logical Framework' (LogFrame) is a tool for project planning and management.
The 'Theory of Change' is a comprehensive description of how and why a desired change is expected to happen.
The 'Monitoring and Evaluation' (M&E) framework tracks progress and measures the impact of programs.
The 'Key Performance Indicator' (KPI) is a measurable value that demonstrates how effectively a program is achieving key objectives.
The 'Baseline Survey' is conducted before a project begins to measure the initial situation.
The 'Endline Survey' is conducted after a project to measure change from the baseline.
The 'Focus Group Discussion' (FGD) is a qualitative data collection method with a small group of people.
The 'Key Informant Interview' (KII) involves in-depth interviews with people who have specific knowledge about a topic.
The 'Stakeholder Analysis' identifies all parties interested in a project and assesses their interests and influence.
The 'SWOT Analysis' assesses Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats related to a program or organization.
The 'Gap Analysis' identifies the difference between the current state and a desired future state.
The 'Needs Assessment' identifies and prioritizes the gaps in services or knowledge within a community.
The 'Resource Mobilization' strategy secures new and continued support for programs.
The 'Sustainability Plan' outlines how a program will continue to operate after initial funding ends.
The 'Advocacy Strategy' is a plan to influence decision-makers to support a specific policy or funding goal.
The 'Policy Brief' is a concise document that summarizes research findings and provides recommendations for policymakers.
The 'Stakeholder Engagement' plan outlines how to involve relevant parties throughout a project.
The 'Risk Management' matrix identifies potential problems and plans how to mitigate them.
The 'Data for Decision-Making' principle emphasizes using evidence to guide programs and policies.
The 'Data Disaggregation' involves breaking down data by categories like age, gender, and location to reveal hidden inequalities.
The 'Data Privacy and Security' protocols protect confidential client information.
The 'Informed Consent' process ensures a client understands a procedure's benefits, risks, and alternatives before agreeing.
The 'Assent' is the agreement of a minor who is not legally able to give full informed consent.
The 'Guardian Consent' is often required for minors to access certain health services.
The 'Mature Minor Doctrine' may allow some adolescents to consent to care based on their understanding, not just age.
The 'Confidentiality' of adolescent clients should be respected to encourage them to seek care.
The 'Duty to Report' may require healthcare workers to break confidentiality in cases of mandatory reporting, like child abuse.
The 'Referral System' ensures clients can access specialized services when needed.
The 'Counter-Referral' slip provides feedback to the original healthcare provider about the services a client received.
The 'Integrated Service Delivery' model provides multiple health services at a single visit, like FP and HIV testing.
The 'One Health' approach recognizes the interconnection between people, animals, and our shared environment.
The 'Climate Change' impacts on health include effects on food security and the spread of infectious diseases.
The 'Health in All Policies' approach considers the health implications of decisions made in all sectors, like education and transportation.
The 'Universal Health Coverage' (UHC) aims to ensure all people have access to needed health services without financial hardship.
The 'Out-of-Pocket Expenditure' is direct payment for health services that can be a barrier to access.
The 'Catastrophic Health Expenditure' occurs when out-of-pocket spending pushes a household into poverty.
The 'Health Insurance' can protect individuals from catastrophic health expenditures.
The 'National Health Account' tracks all financial flows in a country's health system.
The 'Domestic Resource Mobilization' for health involves generating funding from within a country.
The 'External Aid' or 'Development Assistance for Health' is funding from international donors.
The 'Fiscal Space for Health' refers to a government's budgetary room to fund health priorities.
The 'Pay-for-Performance' (P4P) scheme provides financial incentives to health workers or facilities for meeting targets.
The 'Results-Based Financing' (RBF) links payments to the verified achievement of results.
The 'Output' is the direct product or service delivered by a project.
The 'Outcome' is the medium-term effect of a project's outputs.
The 'Impact' is the long-term, sustainable change resulting from a project.
The 'Attribution' is the extent to which observed changes can be linked to a specific project.
The 'Contribution' acknowledges that a project is one of several factors leading to a change.
The 'Qualitative Data' is descriptive and conceptual, often collected through interviews or FGDs.
The 'Quantitative Data' is numerical and can be measured, often collected through surveys.
The 'Mixed-Methods Research' combines both qualitative and quantitative approaches.
The 'Longitudinal Study' collects data from the same subjects repeatedly over a period of time.
The 'Cross-Sectional Study' collects data from a population at a single point in time.
The 'Randomized Controlled Trial' (RCT) is a study design that randomly assigns participants to an intervention or control group.
The 'Ethical Review Board' or 'Institutional Review Board' (IRB) approves research protocols to ensure they are ethical.
The 'Do No Harm' principle is a fundamental ethical commitment in all health work.
The 'Cultural Competency' is the ability to understand and effectively interact with people from different cultures.
The 'Cultural Humility' is a lifelong process of self-reflection to understand one's own biases and to learn from others.
The 'Trauma-Informed Care' approach recognizes the widespread impact of trauma and seeks to avoid re-traumatization.
The 'Psychological First Aid' is a humane, supportive response to someone suffering from distress.
The 'Mental Health and Psychosocial Support' (MHPSS) includes a range of services from community support to clinical care.
The 'Gender-Based Violence Information Management System' (GBVIMS) is a standardized system for safely collecting and managing GBV data.
The 'Survivor-Centered Approach' prioritizes the rights, needs, and wishes of a survivor of violence.
The 'Clinical Management of Rape' (CMR) includes medical care, emergency contraception, PEP, and STI treatment.
The 'Forensic Evidence' collection must be done by a trained professional following a strict protocol.
The 'Safety Planning' helps a survivor of violence identify strategies to increase their safety.
The 'Power and Control Wheel' illustrates the tactics an abuser uses to maintain control in a relationship.
The 'Equality Wheel' shows the qualities of a healthy, non-violent relationship.
The 'Bystander Intervention' teaches individuals how to safely intervene when they witness harassment or violence.
The 'Biological Sex' refers to anatomical, physiological, and genetic characteristics.
The 'Gender Identity' is a person's internal, deeply held sense of their gender.
The 'Gender Expression' is how a person presents their gender through behavior and appearance.
The 'Sexual Orientation' refers to an enduring pattern of emotional and sexual attraction.
The 'LGBTQI+' acronym stands for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Intersex, and more.
The 'Intersex' person is born with sex characteristics that do not fit typical binary notions of male or female bodies.
The 'Transgender' person has a gender identity that differs from the sex they were assigned at birth.
The 'Cisgender' person has a gender identity that aligns with the sex they were assigned at birth.
The 'Gender Affirming Care' is a supportive form of healthcare for transgender and gender-diverse people.
The 'Men Who Have Sex with Men' (MSM) refers to behavior, not identity, and is a key population for HIV programming.
The 'Harm Reduction' approach for people who use drugs includes needle and syringe programs and opioid substitution therapy.
The 'Sex Worker' is an adult who receives money or goods in exchange for sexual services.
The 'Decriminalization' of sex work is advocated by many public health organizations to reduce violence and improve health access.
The 'Opposition to FGM' is based on its classification as a harmful practice and a violation of human rights.
The 'Sande' and 'Poro' societies are traditional secret societies in Liberia, with the Sande society being involved in the practice of FGM.
The 'Alternative Rite of Passage' programs offer a way to celebrate a girl's transition to adulthood without FGM.
The 'Community Dialogue' is a method to engage communities in discussing and addressing sensitive issues like FGM or child marriage.
The 'Social Norms' are the unwritten rules of behavior that are considered acceptable in a group or society.
The 'Positive Social Norms' can promote health, such as the norm that mothers should breastfeed their infants.
The 'Harmful Social Norms' can damage health, such as the norm that men should be sexually dominant or that women should tolerate violence.
The 'Social Norms Marketing' uses communication strategies to promote positive norms and challenge harmful ones.
The 'Community Mobilization' involves engaging community members to take collective action for a common goal.
The 'Participatory Rural Appraisal' (PRA) is a family of methods for learning about rural life and conditions from local people.
The 'Asset-Based Community Development' (ABCD) focuses on community strengths rather than deficits.
The 'Community Health Worker' (CHW) is a local public health worker who provides basic health services and health education.
The 'Village Health Team' (VHT) is a group of community-selected volunteers who promote health in their village.
The 'Community Drug Distributor' provides preventive medicines, like for neglected tropical diseases, at the community level.
The 'Community Scorecard' is a participatory tool for monitoring and evaluating public services.
The 'Citizen Report Card' collects user feedback on the performance of public services.
The 'Social Accountability' is an approach that empowers citizens to hold the state and service providers accountable.
The 'Right to Information' allows citizens to access information held by public bodies.
The 'Grievance Redress Mechanism' provides a formal process for people to complain and seek resolution for problems with services.
The 'Public Expenditure Tracking Survey' (PETS) follows the flow of public funds to see if they reach the intended facilities.
The 'Service Provision Assessment' (SPA) is a health facility survey that evaluates the availability and quality of services.
The 'Demographic and Health Survey' (DHS) is a nationally representative household survey that provides data on population, health, and nutrition.
The 'Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey' (MICS) is an international household survey program focused on women and children.
The 'Performance, Monitoring, and Accountability 2020' (PMA2020) project provides rapid-turnaround family planning data.
The 'Service Availability and Readiness Assessment' (SARA) is a health facility assessment tool.
The 'Health Workforce' includes all people engaged in actions whose primary intent is to enhance health.
The 'Task Shifting' or 'Task Sharing' delegates tasks to less specialized health workers to address shortages.
The 'Pre-Service Education' is the formal training of health workers before they begin practice.
The 'In-Service Training' is the ongoing training of health workers after they have started practice.
The 'Continuing Professional Development' (CPD) is the lifelong process of maintaining knowledge and skills.
The 'Supportive Supervision' is a process that promotes quality by providing constructive feedback and guidance to health workers.
The 'Clinical Mentoring' pairs a less experienced health worker with an expert to improve clinical skills.
The 'Quality Improvement' (QI) is a continuous, systematic process to achieve measurable improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness of care.
The 'Plan-Do-Study-Act' (PDSA) cycle is a four-step model for carrying out change and improvement.
The 'Root Cause Analysis' (RCA) is a method of problem-solving used for identifying the root causes of faults or problems.
The 'Checklist' is a simple tool to improve adherence to clinical standards, like the WHO Safe Childbirth Checklist.
The 'Infection Prevention and Control' (IPC) practices reduce the risk of infection transmission in healthcare settings.
The 'Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene' (WASH) in health facilities is fundamental for quality care and infection prevention.
The 'Medical Waste' must be safely segregated and disposed of to protect health workers, clients, and the community.
The 'Supply Chain Management' ensures a continuous supply of essential medicines and commodities.
The 'Last Mile Distribution' refers to the final step of delivering supplies to remote or hard-to-reach health facilities.
The 'Stock-Out' occurs when a health facility runs out of a specific medicine or commodity.
The 'Early Warning System' for commodities uses data to predict and prevent stock-outs.
The 'Health Management Information System' (HMIS) collects data from health facilities for decision-making.
The 'District Health Information System 2' (DHIS2) is a platform for collecting and visualizing health data.
The 'Data Quality Audit' (DQA) assesses the accuracy and completeness of health data.
The 'Data Use' involves analyzing and interpreting data to inform decisions at all levels of the health system.
The 'Data Visualization' uses charts, graphs, and maps to make data easier to understand.
The 'Dashboard' is a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
The 'Geographic Information System' (GIS) is used to map health data and identify geographic disparities.
The 'Mobile Health' (mHealth) uses mobile phones for health services and information.
The 'Short Message Service' (SMS) can be used for health reminders and information dissemination.
The 'Interactive Voice Response' (IVR) uses a pre-recorded voice system to provide information or collect data over the phone.
The 'Telemedicine' provides clinical services remotely via telecommunications technology.
The 'Digital Health' encompasses a broad range of technologies, including mHealth, electronic health records, and telehealth.
The 'Interoperability' is the ability of different information systems to exchange and use data.
The 'Data Security' protects digital information from unauthorized access, corruption, or theft.
The 'Informed Consent for Data Sharing' is required when personal health information is shared for purposes beyond direct care.
The 'Anonymization' of data removes personally identifiable information to protect privacy.
The 'Open Data' is data that can be freely used, re-used, and redistributed by anyone.
The 'Big Data' refers to extremely large datasets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns and trends.
The 'Artificial Intelligence' (AI) in health can be used for diagnostics, predicting outbreaks, and personalizing treatment.
The 'Machine Learning' is a type of AI that allows software to become more accurate at predicting outcomes without being explicitly programmed.
The 'Blockchain' technology can be used to create secure and transparent health records.
The 'Internet of Things' (IoT) refers to the network of physical devices connected to the internet, which can include medical devices.
The 'Digital Divide' is the gap between those who have access to modern information technology and those who do not.
The 'Digital Literacy' is the ability to use information and communication technologies to find, evaluate, create, and communicate information.
The 'Fake News' and 'Misinformation' about health can spread rapidly online and cause harm.
The 'Infodemic' is an overabundance of information, both online and offline, during an epidemic, which includes deliberate attempts to disseminate wrong information.
The 'Media Literacy' is the ability to identify different types of media and understand the messages they are sending.
The 'Risk Communication and Community Engagement' (RCCE) is essential during public health emergencies.
The 'Rumor Tracking' identifies and addresses false information circulating in communities.
The 'Community Feedback Mechanism' allows communities to ask questions and report concerns during a health response.
The 'Social Listening' monitors digital conversations to understand public sentiment and emerging concerns.
The 'Crisis Communication' provides timely and accurate information during a public health emergency.
The 'Emergency Preparedness and Response' plan outlines how the health system will function during a crisis.
The 'Resilient Health System' can withstand shocks and stresses, such as disease outbreaks or natural disasters, while maintaining core functions.
